synonyms: Invasive carcinoma of no special type
Invasive breast carcinoma of no special type
Invasive ductal carcinoma, not otherwise specified
summary: Invasive Ductal Carcinoma (IDC) is a type of breast cancer that begins in the milk ducts and has spread into surrounding breast tissue. It is the most common type of invasive breast cancer, accounting for a significant majority of diagnoses in women and also occurring in men. It is characterized by cells that have invaded beyond the duct walls but lack specific differentiating features of other invasive breast cancer types, making it a diagnosis of exclusion. The disease can spread to nearby lymph nodes or metastasize to distant parts of the body through the lymphatic system or bloodstream. Prognosis varies based on factors like tumor grade, stage, and receptor status.
causes: Genetic changes in BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes
risk_factors: History of breast cancer or benign breast disease
Inherited risk of breast cancer (e.g., BRCA1/BRCA2 gene changes)
Reproductive history leading to increased estrogen exposure (early menstruation, late first birth, late menopause)
Radiation therapy to the breast or chest
Being Black (tend to have greater severity and worse survival)
symptoms: New lump or thickening in or near the breast or armpit
Change in breast size or shape
Dimple or puckering in breast skin (orange peel-like texture)
Nipple discharge (sudden, bloody, or from one breast)
Scaly, red, or swollen skin in the nipple area or breast
Metastatic symptoms depending on affected organ
diagnosis: Blood chemistry tests (BMP, CMP, electrolyte panel)
DNA analysis (diploid vs. aneuploid, S phase percentage)
Microscopic evaluation of carcinomatous cells below basement membrane of lactiferous ducts invading stroma
treatments: Targeted therapy (e.g., trastuzumab for HER2-positive tumors)
subtypes: Carcinoma with osteoclast-like stromal giant cells
